raw_text:
Gronkjaer agrees switch to Madrid
 
 Jesper Gronkjaer has agreed a move to Atletico Madrid from Birmingham City.
 
 The 27-year-old winger spent just five months at St Andrews following a £2.2m move from Chelsea in July after playing for Denmark at Euro 2004. He is set to move during the January transfer window in a deal rumoured to be about £1.4m, subject to a medical. "We will meet with the player's representative to finalise the contract and decide when he will sign," said Atletico sporting director Toni Munoz. Gronkjaer has been targeted by Blues fans and was sarcastically applauded when taken off against Everton last month. Boss Steve Bruce had said that he would be happy to let the Danish international go if the price was right. He added: "I'm not going to say the decision to let him go is down to the fans' reaction towards him.
 
 "He has had a tough time since the summer with the loss of his mother and finding it difficult to adjust to a new club and a different area. "He has been terrific and not missed a day's training and is someone if your daughter brought them home you would be delighted. "It just hasn't quite worked out here for him. But we'd like to get back most of what we spent."

The 27-year-old winger has been targeted by Blues fans and faced criticism for his time at St Andrews before being moved back home.
He will leave during the January transfer window with boss Steve Bruce saying that while the decision is not solely based on fan reaction.

The transfer is expected to happen during the January transfer window and is subject to a medical.

Gronkjaer was targeted by fans at Birmingham and Steve Bruce indicated he would be willing to sell him if the right price was offered, although Gronkjaer has received positive feedback from manager Steve Bruce who notes his professionalism despite personal difficulties since joining the club.

He will spend five months at St Andrews and is set to move during January in a deal that could be worth about £1.4m, subject to a medical condition.
Gronkjaer has been targeted by fans and was praised when he was taken off against Everton last month.
The Danish international boss Steve Bruce said the move would be a "happy thing" for him.
He added: "I'm not going to say the decision to let him go is down to the fans' reaction towards him.
He has had a tough time since the summer with the loss of his mother and finding it difficult to adjust to a new club and a different area."
Gronkjaer's performance was not missed by the Danish international, which means he will be great for Atletico Madrid.

He will sign during the January transfer window and is expected to leave his current club, Everton, at the end of the transfer window.
Gronkjaer was taken off last month against Everton and has been targeted by Blues fans, but he has not been given a formal reason for his departure from Everton.
He has been praised by his team's management for his performance in the summer, but there is no indication that this will be enough to persuade him to stay at Everton.

The deal is set to start during the January transfer window at a reported £1.4m cost.

Gronkjaer has faced challenges, including losing his mother, adjusting to a new club, and a tough time while playing well but not fully fitting in at Atletico.

Gronkjaer will not be signed until January 2018, subject to a medical.
The winger has been heavily criticized by Blues fans due to his performances under Steve Bruce and will face a hostile reception upon his return to the Premier League.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Jesper Gronkjaer, a 27-year-old Danish winger, has agreed to transfer from Birmingham City to Atletico Madrid during the January transfer window.
The deal is reportedly worth approximately £1.4 million, contingent on a successful medical.
Gronkjaer joined Birmingham in July for £2.2 million following his release from Chelsea.
His tenure at St Andrews was brief, spanning only five months due to the challenges of adapting to a new city and club after his mother's death over the summer.
Despite initial difficulties, he maintained consistency in training, earning positive feedback from Bruce.
However, fans' reception was initially negative, often sarcastically applauding him when substituted.
Manager Steve Bruce, acknowledging Gronkjaer's dedication and potential, agreed to let him go for the right price, expressing hope to recover some of their initial investment.
